channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: The Dwarves Of Auschwitz
item.description: The story of a family of dwarves snatched from the gas chamber by Josef Mengele himself sounded incredible. But how to verify the testimony of Holocaust survivors? And should you even try?

item.title: Why Does The U.S. Navy Still Own Wooden-Hulled Warships?
item.description: Everyone likes a real wood deck.

item.title: The Mystery Of Glass Exploding At 130,000 FPS
item.description: Here's a really neat video looking at the unusual qualities of Prince Rupert's Drop.

item.title: IRS Uses Tax Money For 'Star Trek' Spoof
item.description: It appears there’s no sign of intelligent life at the Internal Revenue Service. They created Star Trek and Gilligan’s Island spoofs that cost tax payers $60,000.

item.title: Most Shocking Thing About Canada's Chemical Valley? People Live There
item.description: Collectively forming a post-human landscape, more than 60 oil refineries and petro-chemical plants—40 percent of Canada’s total chemical industry—operate within 15 miles of the valley.

item.title: Lawmakers Seek To Ban Google Glass On The Road
item.description: West Virginia lawmakers are already pouncing on the existence of Google Glass and introducing a bill that would prohibit drivers from making a spectacle of themselves.

item.title: Major Security Hole Allowed Apple Passwords To Be Reset With Only Email Address And Date Of Birth
item.description: Apple rolled out two-step verification, a security measure that promises to further shield Apple ID and iCloud accounts from being hijacked. Unfortunately, a new exploit was discovered that affected all customers who hadn't yet enabled the new feature.

item.title: Florida Passes Bill Banning Internet Cafes
item.description: Internet cafes across the state could soon be forced to close their doors.

item.title: If 'Star Wars' Was Dubbed With 'Jurassic Park'
item.description: You know you would see this movie.

item.title: Are We Too Naive About Where We're Putting Our Data?
item.description: Maybe we’re too caught up in ever-changing trends to have a moment to stop and think about the digital wake we create or what responsibility it is of anyone to manage it.

item.title: The Dystopian Technology That Could Make Breaking The Law Impossible
item.description: High-tech, fully-automated code enforcement could be a boon for city coffers.

item.title: What It's Like To Dine At Disneyland's Super-Exclusive Restaurant
item.description: Everyone's heard the whispers about Disneyland's exclusive hideaway, but only a select few have stepped foot inside Club 33.

item.title: The Science Of Happiness
item.description: A researcher spent 38 years asking whether his college classmates were happy. You don't have to have been in his class to learn something from the results.

item.title: Can Drones Save The Elephants?
item.description: This week, 89 African elephants in southern Chad were slaughtered for their ivory tusks. To stop the massacre of these stately beasts, conservation groups are fighting poachers with eye-in-the-sky drones.

item.title: The Social Media Guide To Ruining Your Relationship
item.description: Everything that's allegedly great about communication for humans is terrible for romance.

item.title: The Age Of The Russian Oligarch Comes To An End
item.description: Boris Berezovsky, the self-made billionaire and archetypical Russian oligarch, has died at the age of 67 in London, where he had lived since falling out with the Putin-led Kremlin more than a decade ago. In a sense, his death marks the end of the original age of Russian oligarchs.

item.title: Florida’s Parallel Universe
item.description: The abandoned Nike Missile Site, surrounded by the Everglades, is a reminder of when humans almost destroyed the world and a warning that we could still lose everything today.

item.title: You Might Be A Martian
item.description: The Curiosity rover found gray mud on the red planet, suggesting that there may have been life—and that we might be descended from it.

item.title: Newtown Victim's Parents Describe Meeting With Adam Lanza's Father
item.description: When Alissa and Robbie Parker met face to face recently with the father of the young man who killed their daughter and 19 other first-graders at Sandy Hook Elementary School, they weren't angry with him and didn't blame him for the massacre.

item.title: Britain's Most Accomplished Cat Burglar Gets An Awesome Obituary
item.description: Peter Scott, who has died aged 82, was a highly accomplished cat burglar, and as Britain’s most prolific plunderer of the great and good took particular pains to select his victims from the ranks of aristocrats, film stars and even royalty.

item.title: JJ Abrams Reveals His Vision For 'Man Of Steel'
item.description: The "Star Trek" director talks about how his leaked "Superman Flyby" is turning out to look a lot like Zack Snyder's "Man Of Steel."

item.title: 10 White People Who Inexplicably Became Ninjas
item.description: It’s like ninjas have their own version of Affirmative Action just for white guys, and thus several Euro-Americans have managed to snag honorary ninja degrees when they had no business doing so.

item.title: Tilda Swinton Is Currently Sleeping In A Box At MoMA
item.description: On random days this month, Tilda Swinton (actress, Bowie-enthusiast, badass) will be performing her 1995 piece "The Maybe," which consists of Swinton sleeping in a glass box.

item.title: Websites Can Legally Pirate Porn Movies, Prosecutors Rule
item.description: This week prosecutors made the decision not to prosecute the alleged pirates, ruling that since pornography is obscene it isn’t worthy of copyright protection.

item.title: How To Get Real Eggs On Your McDonald's Breakfast Sandwich
item.description: You can get your McDonald's biscuit sandwiches (or any breakfast sandwich, for that matter) made with a 100% real egg, cracked and cooked fresh on-premises.

item.title: Your Laser Pointer Is Probably Illegal
item.description: A new study shows a majority of the dinky laser pointers on the market exceed the power level limits set by the Code of Federal Regulations, which means a whole lot of twerps out there wield far more retina-burning power than they should.

item.title: The Story Of Earth In 2 Minutes And 20 Seconds
item.description: How old is the Earth, how long did it take for life to appear?
